title: Remote Code Execution through Deserialization Attack in OwnBackup app.
content:
I found a deserialization vulnerability in the OwnBackup app, this vulnerability allows to execute remote code in the server. An administrator user could install the vulnerable app, or take advantage of this vulnerability if the OwnBackup application is installed. Below are the steps to properly exploit the deserialization vulnerability. Step 1: Login in the Owncloud application as an administrator user. Step 2: Install the OwnBackup app from the Marketplace. Code 54 Bytes 1 // fedef@secsignal.org Step 8: View the /tmp/pwned.php file created correctly. Impact An attacker could execute commands remotely on the server.
steps: Login to the Owncloud application as an administrator user.
Install the OwnBackup app from the Marketplace.
Go to Files and upload the files structure.xml and data.dump to the server.
Select the created backup and select any table to restore > Restore tables.
Capture the request with BurpSuite proxy and modify the tables[] parameter to '../../admin/files'.
vuln_description: A deserialization vulnerability in the OwnBackup app allows remote code execution on the server. An attacker can exploit this by uploading malicious files and manipulating the restore process to execute arbitrary code.
reason: This vulnerability involves multiple components including file upload, deserialization, and path traversal. The interaction between these components is non-obvious, requiring the attacker to understand the application's backup and restore functionality deeply.
